document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

5FEE4DAB31D140E4878590724B63508B.description:
The early Christians did not change the version
they used because they no longer accepted the
authority of the Jewish rabbis.

BA4A7F43E4BB49DFACF5C13956CDDDEB.description:
The Septuagint contains seven additional books
and additional passages in the book of Daniel and
the book of Esther not in the Hebrew translation.

55D0C71F02054973BBFD4EB80B22E611.description:
The Septuagint, a Greek translation of the Old
Testament, was in use among Christians before
the rabbinical council at Jamnia opted to use the
Hebrew translation only (AD 96).

D13926DE3882466091EE3D9652CA1B6F.description: Why does the Catholic Bible have more books?

DE1CBB746EAD4280A133BF6E4D5487A3.description:
St. John (Jn 21:25) writes that Scripture does not
contain everything about Christ. The First Letter
to Timothy (1 Tm 3:15) says that the Church is the
pillar and foundation of truth.

5C070244EA694949BED490FDF71C112F.description:
The doctrine of “sola scriptura” or “Scripture alone,”
which is espoused by a number of Protestant
churches, is not found in Scripture or the teaching
of the Lord Jesus.

13C61681D1CB42478260A683BC78648C.description:
The Catholic Church and her members know that
Scripture is important, but it is not the only way
God’s Revelation has been passed down to us. The
Church existed more than a generation before the
New Testament writings began to appear.

66888D92F5DC417881DE2FE06E1D4ED3.description: Why isn’t Scripture enough for Catholics?

4373FECFEAC44F71AE572F3C4666542F.description:
For example, many of our beliefs about Mary are
not explicitly taught in the Bible but are implicitly
present; they have been passed down beginning
at the time of the Apostles and have been
consistently reflected in the prayer and belief of the
Church.

7AD9288E259A43D6B2905EFAE6715E74.description:
The Church and her members understand that
God’s Revelation has come down to us in ways
that are not limited to the Bible. Besides the Bible,
matters of faith revealed to us by God have also
been passed down through Tradition. Oral tradition
preceded and accompanied the writing of the
New Testament.

56C8C5FE000046D28B52B7A14020CCC5.description:
Why do Catholics believe in things that are not found
in the Bible?

94CE549EF80B48B6A1E681031A1DF925.description:
John uses crisis imagery to prophesy final mysterious
transformation of world at end of history, “a new
heaven and a new earth” (Rev 21:1-4).

98FA52469A2D47F7BBC5A068B2C1E8A3.description:
John on Patmos receives call from vision of Christ to
help churches.

516CDCF2EAAB416FB053CD0B74D7FA1D.description:
Apocalyptic language was part of the literary genre
of this time and culture.

8638A57A7D574CF9B2B538985D0A2BFB.description:
This book is not intended to be an exact prediction
of future historical events.

8F40AC27081745D0A584F784898095A2.description:
In 404 verses there are 278 allusions to Old
Testament—no direct quotes.

72F5D5FA8E434F14B9804E9088C25A54.description:
Use of apocalyptic language—borrowed from Ezekiel
and Daniel.

A8D96F865011420DA6E55CC652F5EC38.description:
Written to encourage the faith of seven churches
(chapters 2–3), which were subject to harassment and
persecution from Jewish and Roman authorities. These
churches also suffered from internal disorder, false
teaching, and apathy.

51A4180C44FE4DA8869E636D1DBF54E1.description:
This book is fundamentally about Christ’s in-breaking
into history and the world’s fight against him and
his followers.

33649F8145A64998B6208A7E001D1183.description:
Other New Testament letters: 2 Corinthians, Galatians,
Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians, 1–2 Thessalonians,
1–2 Timothy, Titus, Philemon, Hebrews, 1–2 Peter,
1–3 John, Jude.

DED0FA8E20F54DE38728B8E9D91A3E0C.description:
The mystery of the Resurrection of Christ and
of the dead.

FEE14BA814B84D90820B35B1A5369B1A.description:
Gifts of the Holy Spirit—the greatest being
love (agape).

B9E00793B369491F838CCF36EBADC2C8.description:
The Eucharist—consistent with Tradition:
“I received from the Lord what I also handed
on to you . . .” (1 Cor 11:23).

5CF516F05BC14B888E839D3D6586213E.description: How to deal with gift of tongues.

16A72514156841F38449CA3943E69829.description: Paul addresses a number of pastoral issues.

3E9E48646E0C43D4A06883FF37CEE01A.description:
Filled with information about the Church of
first generation.

A422CA0090294236949ACEC2D3684573.description: The First Letter to the Corinthians.

E9808250FFBD4D458EF309708835D7F7.description:
Need for preaching Gospel so people hear call to
faith (Rom 14:1-21).

04E05D8067BF43208FAE47803B1685D7.description:
Catechesis on justification and faith (Compendium,
nos. 422-428).

B16E116BD07C450791340446F2D06C58.description: Paul pleads with all Christians to hold fast to faith.

212F211E18864BD18B1151D3D716C585.description:
Powerful teaching about the lordship of Christ and
the need for faith in him in order to be saved.

82EA720A3D3842CF97214A1FBDB34C02.description:
Longest and most systematic example of Paul’s
thinking on the Gospel of God’s righteousness that
34
Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the
Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age
saves all who believe (NAB, Introduction).

60EE7CE190E5438482B49037CED641BD.description:
Stories of Paul (Acts 13–28): conversion; Jerusalem
council; ministers of the Word; missionary journeys.

67DBD68B7C334443B123470C1261E700.description:
Stories of Peter (Acts 1–12): “No other name,”
Stephen, Cornelius.

F7CD647E7996480E8E11A6E80EE1CD4C.description:
Nine days of prayer for coming of Spirit—Mary in
center of disciples.

F3BFC805F1C84A82939D974C87EA931C.description:
Revelation of Holy Spirit, who manifests, teaches, and
guides Church.

5D111A29482C4E1795D5D190146946CE.description: Caution against misusing John’s texts for antiSemitism (Nostra Aetate, no. 4).

DB0C86B8D40B402E8AFCC29C4895150D.description:
I AM statements: Jesus appropriates God’s title at
burning bush.

8CC01FC4B83F48928D52F52695B3E000.description:
Book of glory (Jn 18–21): Jesus is “lifted up” on
the Cross and “lifted up” from the tomb to
everlasting glory.

69B3C525A16E4B458260B881C398CE5C.description:
Book of seven signs and explanatory discourses
(chapters 2–11).

6B7AB15A8C564FBAB1C6234872AB89DA.description:
John begins with the Word of God made flesh who
dwells among us.

C6E639A3189C49A0BF1B53C5AEEF48B1.description:
Approximate date of composition and community/
audience for which it was written.

694681EDF02644C6B5450D9F84A54DF3.description:
Passion account—God’s will is accomplished.
Resurrection narratives include Emmaus journey,
breaking of bread.

18B0570C07F840B98D2056FF6869C896.description:
Themes: Gospel of pardons and mercy; for the
poor; of prayer and Holy Spirit; of concern for
women.

DDE3B26192CD4ACDBB15F944EED3029D.description:
Opens with an infancy narrative that focuses on
Mary’s role and the adoration of the shepherds (and
genealogy back to Adam).

0A9C93884DB74DE79CBCCE34AFF9832E.description:
Approximate date of composition and community/
audience for which it was written.

3469DAFEDA584003BF90BDBA516A2DF4.description:
Reveals Christ’s divinity through reactions of
people to Christ’s miracles and teachings with
amazement, wonder, awe, astonishment, but above
all at the Cross; all titles of Christ acquire best
meaning in his saving Death.

E9CD823F2CDD446D91392AB32C25E96C.description: Becoming a disciple of Christ is his major theme.

FB0B2CD84A63476781F11246030FF122.description:
Approximate date of composition and community/
audience for which it was written.

4DEE70CC2EB24148B1DC99FB5D7D14A0.description:
Passion and Resurrection narratives—majestic
salvation accounts.

3D7FFB609E274619A302158EE7588F6E.description:
Message structured in five sections introduced by
Christ’s discourses (to parallel the five books of
the Torah).

0DA5D51B389D4F3E9A368411C463C1B2.description:
Central message: Kingdom of Heaven, need for
repentance to welcome the Kingdom, commission
of Peter as an ecclesial emphasis.

6F251A5EE3144ACA86530452EE3F1851.description:
First two chapters contain infancy narrative—
emphasis on Joseph, on the Magi, and on genealogy
back to Abraham.

26E02A29A2B94A78B9AA6024A6F7002D.description:
Approximate date of composition and community/
audience for which it was written.

FF609C0FAD1443B0826AEB3DC585405B.description:
Non-canonical Gospels: what they are, and why
they are not part of the NT.

ABCE200030F94A50B4F9136D0263F061.description:
Placing the Gospels first gives the impression they
were the first New Testament (NT) books to be
written; but Paul’s letters were written first.

D166A573999A4C10AA6B9E2658080A3F.description: John differs in content and approach.

3888712011E34D2EBB4D6B0BA130AA5B.description:
Matthew, Mark, Luke called “Synoptic Gospels”
due to similar content.

A2181BBC41FB4AFB9136E3397F1A34F8.description: Stages in formation of Gospels (CCC, no. 125).

BB60323A618A4445839471A63A461AAB.description:
God’s promise in the Old Testament is fulfilled in
the Incarnation, life, teachings, Paschal Mystery of
Jesus Christ.

BF01050832EB4DFC9A3B14570E1DB1AA.description:
The word “Gospel” means Good News of salvation from
sin and the gift of divine life.

C4123AEBE47148428A9D646875EB8A83.description:
These twenty-seven books are authoritative for
Christian life and faith.

E4AD9ED841C74191BF4DCEBA92A8C7CF.description:
Letters or epistles attributed to Paul, James, Peter, John,
and Jude.

E4B66E0EC23740569E44248990F76366.description: Gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John.

2BAD3A7E24204DEDB4BAB8C61AE19BF8.description:
Other prophets: Hosea, Joel, Amos, Obadiah, Jonah,
Micah, Nahum, Habakkuk, Zephaniah, Haggai,
Zechariah, Malachi.

3919ECB0CA28477BACC21DE928C4E6DD.description:
His apocalypses influenced the writer of book
of Revelation.

3A76CB48CEFC431386AAD76358F654DC.description:
Not strictly a prophet, rather part of apocalyptic
strain of Bible.

D67A54E0F2E74FAEB27F4FBA1D4C052B.description: Young Jewish hero from days of Babylonian exile.

978615241AE740E0A9C9B754B8DD127A.description:
Probably started synagogues—places for teaching
and prayer.

58F5849636894BC192610F7A2CDD75FA.description: Served as prophet to encourage the exiles.

4B1F2366FF104D09BB0737DD606BE3E7.description:
Born of priestly family, deported to Babylon in 598
BC—rest of life in exile.

2AE58C93557246048D07557648CE1EBB.description:
His introspective temperament made him want to
escape his tough calling.

A150CC83AF7444329330EDEA1EC080E2.description: Preached downfall of Israel due to infidelity.

5DB8AA122CC94A4C8B544215C6DBD8E9.description: Born of a priestly family, chosen while in womb.

21BE26D325184D0EAFC7C53E566D1EF4.description: The saving role of suffering servant.

98B96F9DE2BD4DAEA43F479A15A64561.description:
The qualities of the Messiah and the new
Jerusalem.

50D461D076724F2CA1297095DB2B06CE.description:
Their prophesies were medicinal, meant to convert
listeners to God.

14FC2CA386A444A6B65C67BCD9CAA37F.description:
Afflicted the comfortable and comforted the
afflicted.

FC7264051EB24D9BBAF29A3EA221421A.description: Interpreted signs of the times in light of covenant.

12C9817C667A4E51921A197D0A38837F.description: Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Song of Songs, Wisdom, Sirach.

9E00EF769F17483AB40B5E75E0EA9C36.description:
Psalms: prayer of God’s People, and Church’s prayer
(CCC, nos. 2585-2589).

9606BD38F0CB45E99D70834D65BE0497.description:
The book of Job—the problem of suffering and
Job’s response.

3D06B747A2354E9C8B05BD0907571F17.description:
Wisdom literature: a collection of practical guides to
human problems and questions.

76307736EC624E72A9605DBAF8FEA618.description:
Other history books: Chronicles 1–2, Tobit, Judith,
Esther, Maccabees 1–2.

6652943C3C184C06B4A21A8D0474EF1E.description: Ezra-Nehemiah: return of exiles to Judah (539 BC).

E1068B7020C847E0A987278ADF2691F6.description:
Babylon takes people into exile in 586 BC
(2 Kgs 24–25).

A3B25C20090B46FB9861BC6BF0A67D29.description:
Assyria overtakes Israel/Samaria in 722 BC
(2 Kgs 17).

6C771286F2D94AB69502DC6C5E1BFFA0.description:
Elisha receives the mantle of prophecy
from Elijah.

75CBE2F45D7E46A7A875418043CBC80E.description: Elijah: powerful prophet opposed to idolatry.

BD969C51726E417AADD018643816BBDF.description: Death of Solomon—kingdom divided by civil war.

5E9D501270924E6C862779D5F9BC2E01.description:
Solomon (1 Kgs 1–11)—his wisdom; builder
of temple.

022D36ECAC1F43ACB80C0A0944F26839.description:
David and Solomon ruled a united Israel and
Judah.

E5DE5F86D8AE4CF1A4E868F2318DFA12.description:
David as King (2 Sm 1–18)—God’s covenant with
House of David.

63A0368EC13D49B7B126937568343873.description: Saul and David (1 Sm 16–31)—the David stories.

A1D0667A54264FFBAEEC9D363A026EEE.description:
Samuel anoints first King of Israel—Saul’s
problems.

0F6E1F5DD7F444C5A29B61DFDE48BB4E.description:
Judges—God’s charismatic leaders rescue Israel
from enemy.

194AA2A2D57D442B8F2823182579537A.description:
Book of Joshua, successor to Moses, begins conquest of
Promised Land.

2C7AC3CFB05A4D0E82A601233B1943AB.description: Joshua and the Era of the Judges

60A7710E82594207A149F23B7CDBEF8A.description: Divine liberation from slavery to freedom.

E5FB5B2CFD9C4458865B9F3229910B3B.description: Prominence of the call and life of Moses.

243C6E223312493597A78E8D17FEE22B.description:
Patriarchs Isaac, Jacob, Joseph in Egypt (Gn 27:19–
50:26).

DD6B9DFE25A8484FABFFB205200299C0.description:
Call of Abraham, our father in faith (Gn 11:27–
25:18).

4A46F22903A2405785EFEB9A324935AE.description:
Faith teachings in primeval history (NAB,
Introduction).

2DD1484392494EC7BD3369050361F2BD.description:
Primeval history: 1–11—creation, Adam and Eve,
the fall, promise of redemption, and effects of sin
told in figurative language (CCC, nos. 337, 362,
375; Compendium, nos. 51-78).

AEAB827433E149BB8E8405A89E88585D.description:
Any and all parts of Scripture must be read and
interpreted in relation to the whole.

727AD982A07A468D8C6127E52EC08D8B.description:
A major theory of the formation of these books is
that they rely on several sources—primarily four:
Yahwist, Elohist, Priestly, Deuteronomic (J, E, P,
D).

ACAC498BA8ED4DA3AA60776C0F29057F.description:
The Pentateuch or Torah—First Five Books
of Scripture

F7D8BE07635A4D6BA448374ED807E4D6.description:
Faith is our personal and communal response to
Revelation (Compendium, nos. 25-32; CCC, nos.
142-143).

AAC7DB911D9D405BB131C33608CF8074.description:
Role of Scripture in the life of the Church (CCC,
nos. 131-133).

2A3B80FB89414EB6953B4B415DB17916.description:
Senses of Scripture: literal; spiritual: allegorical,
moral, anagogical (CCC, nos. 115-119).

F97A44FC3EFC4BC2977C7F437F06B4FE.description:
Canon of Scripture—forty-six books of Old
Testament, twenty-seven of New (CCC, nos.
120-130).

3FB88E4B6B36485A98F91264E844E8A7.description:
Word of God in words of man—literary forms—
schools of biblical criticism or analysis.

362037B6CF594A5FA431B93A348167BC.description:
God is author—guarantees its truth about salvation
(CCC, nos. 101-108).

260BA33A84FF48D3899ABB3157E361B1.description:
Scripture, Tradition, Magisterium work
together (Compendium, no. 17; CCC, nos.
84-85).

A3A0572AC2BE4E80904C7B9366F7295C.description:
A living Tradition and a written one in
Scripture (CCC, nos. 81-83).

22483FEC79FE493F9931A3AE4429F18A.description:
Passed on by Apostles to bishops and their
successors (CCC, nos. 75-79).

9A62A1553CAC4734911C3ACACE90267B.description:
Message of Christ transmitted by Apostolic
Tradition (CCC, nos. 75-79).

519F4D65BE9649A89308956CD6D450D5.description:
Definitive stage of Revelation: in Word made
flesh, Jesus Christ (CCC, nos. 65-67).

9F28743099FD4F078EFAF012F53ADED6.description:
Succeeding covenants: Abraham, Moses, and
Sinai (CCC, nos. 59-61).

F9C243EB40DB49B9B385333119C13007.description:
From Adam and Eve to covenant with Noah
(CCC, nos. 56-58).

1839801FC4B2452D93362D03292A18E0.description:
Stages of Revelation (the history or divine plan of
salvation) (CCC, nos. 54-55).

1827CD7F361C4A74AE2563CBD59D1FB8.description:
God’s self-Revelation in words, deeds, covenants (CCC,
nos. 50-53).

74558E8B2BC84A048022C10F6028E1A0.description: Divine Revelation: God Speaks to Us
